weka.classifiers.timeseries.core
Class TSLagMaker.PeriodicityHandler

java.lang.Object
  weka.classifiers.timeseries.core.TSLagMaker.PeriodicityHandler
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
Enclosing class:
TSLagMaker
public static class TSLagMaker.PeriodicityHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

Helper class to manage time stamp manipulation with respect to various periodicities. Has a routine to remap the time stamp, which is useful for date time stamps. Since dates are just manipulated internally as the number of milliseconds elapsed since the epoch, and any global trend modelling in regression functions results in enormous coefficients for this variable - remapping to a more reasonable scale prevents this. It also makes it easier to handle the case where there are time periods that shouldn't be considered as a time unit increment, e.g. weekends and public holidays for financial trading data. These "holes" in the data can be accomodated by accumulating a negative offset for the remapped date when a particular data/time occurs in a user-specified "skip" list.

Author:
Mark Hall (mhall{[at]}pentaho{[dot]}com)
See Also:

Parameters:

dateFormat - a default date format to use for parsing dates

remapDateTimeStamp

public Instance remapDateTimeStamp(Instance inst,
                                   Instance previous,
                                   java.lang.String timeStampName)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
Remaps a date timestamp to an integer starting (from the first time stamp seen in the data) at 0. This is makes any coefficients produced by a regression model for the timestamp (global trend modelling) of reasonable scale. It is also useful for dealing with time units that shouldn't be considered an increment as a negative adjustment can be accumulated for these.

Parameters:
inst - the instance containing a date timestamp to be remapped
previous - the immediately previous instance in the sequence (may be null).
timeStampName - the name of the timestamp attribute
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if an error occurs
